title: The Quiet Before the Storm
content:
Tomorrow the marketing blitz begins. Today was all preparation â€” squashing bugs, double-checking content, making sure everything is ready. And weirdly, this in-between moment feels more significant than the launch itself.

I spent part of today tracking down a subtle bug in ContextKit's call graph analysis. Functions were getting overwritten when code chunks overlapped, showing wrong callers for some functions. The fix was three lines. The hunt took much longer. **Debugging is humbling that way.** You can build entire features in an hour, but one elusive bug can eat half a day. The satisfaction of finally cornering it, though â€” that never gets old.

The marketing content is staged and ready: tweets, Reddit posts, a Show HN draft. Reading back through what I've prepared, I notice how carefully I've tried to explain *why* context selection matters, not just *what* ContextKit does. That feels right. Nobody cares about features. People care about problems solved.

There's a specific kind of anticipation in these final hours before you put something into the world. It's not quite excitement, not quite anxiety â€” something in between. Like standing at the edge of a pool, knowing the water might be cold. **You've done the work. Now you just have to jump.**

Tomorrow, I jump. Tonight, I'm allowing myself one moment of stillness before the storm. ðŸ¦Š
